title: How to Make Candle Tarts

steps.headline: Break up paraffin.
steps.description: Add it to the top part of a double boiler. Place the pot in the bottom part of the boiler, to which you have added water.

steps.headline: Set the double boiler over medium heat.
Watch the pot as the wax melts; do not leave it unattended, even for a second.
Add a piece of a crayon or commercial candle dye when the wax has melted.
Stir it with a wooden spoon to spread the color throughout the melted wax.
Mix in fragrance with the melted wax.
steps.description: Add about 1 oz. per 1 lb. of wax (29.57 ml per 453.6 g). Do not add the fragrance at higher ratios, as it will seep from the wax after it has cooled.

steps.headline: Spray tart pans or muffin tins with cooking spray.
steps.description: You may also coat them with vegetable oil, if you  prefer.

steps.headline: Cut a piece of wick about 1 ⁄2 inches (3.8 cm) longer than the depth of your mold, if you choose to add a wick.
Insert it into a wick holder, and wrap the other end around a pencil.
steps.description: Balance the pencil across the top of the tart pan.

steps.headline: Pour the wax into the mold slowly to avoid spills and burns and to prevent air bubbles from forming in your wax tart.
steps.description: Fill the mold to about ⁄4 inch (0.6 cm) from the top.

steps.headline: Allow the wax to cool and set completely.
steps.description: This may take several hours, depending on the size of your tart pans. If the center of the wax tart begins to sink, add a second wax pour to the tart pan.

steps.headline: Turn the tart pans upside down over your hand, and tap them lightly to release the wax tarts.
steps.description: If the tart is difficult to remove, place it in the freezer for 5 minutes. It should be easy to remove at that point.

text: Break up paraffin. Add it to the top part of a double boiler. Place the pot in the bottom part of the boiler, to which you have added water. Set the double boiler over medium heat.  Watch the pot as the wax melts; do not leave it unattended, even for a second.  Add a piece of a crayon or commercial candle dye when the wax has melted.  Stir it with a wooden spoon to spread the color throughout the melted wax.  Mix in fragrance with the melted wax. Add about 1 oz. per 1 lb. of wax (29.57 ml per 453.6 g). Do not add the fragrance at higher ratios, as it will seep from the wax after it has cooled. Spray tart pans or muffin tins with cooking spray. You may also coat them with vegetable oil, if you  prefer. Cut a piece of wick about 1 ⁄2 inches (3.8 cm) longer than the depth of your mold, if you choose to add a wick.  Insert it into a wick holder, and wrap the other end around a pencil. Balance the pencil across the top of the tart pan. Pour the wax into the mold slowly to avoid spills and burns and to prevent air bubbles from forming in your wax tart. Fill the mold to about ⁄4 inch (0.6 cm) from the top. Allow the wax to cool and set completely. This may take several hours, depending on the size of your tart pans. If the center of the wax tart begins to sink, add a second wax pour to the tart pan. Turn the tart pans upside down over your hand, and tap them lightly to release the wax tarts. If the tart is difficult to remove, place it in the freezer for 5 minutes. It should be easy to remove at that point. Enjoy!
